title: 109_hr3672
content: The Act titled "TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005" allows for the advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 authorizes advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006, extending activities through December 31, 2005. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 allows payments to be made through the first quarter of fiscal year 2006 at the same level as in 2005. Amendments are made to various sections of the Social Security Act, extending activities until December 31, 2005. The National Random Sample Study of Child Welfare and Child Welfare Waiver Authority is extended through December 31, 2005, with appropriations made for necessary funds. Grants and payments can continue through the first quarter of fiscal year 2006 at the same level as in 2005. Reimbursement of states for TANF benefits provided to assist families affected by Hurricane Katrina. Eligibility for Payments From the Contingency Fund for needy States affected by Hurricane Katrina, providing short-term, nonrecurring cash benefits to families who have relocated due to the hurricane. The State must confirm that families are not receiving cash benefits from any other program. The total payment to a needy State cannot exceed the cash benefits provided to eligible families. No state match is required for payments under this section. SEC. 4. AVAILABILITY OF ADDITIONAL TANF FUNDS FOR HURRICANE-DAMAGED STATES. Beginning with the date of the enactment of this Act and ending with the end of fiscal year 2006, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama are eligible for loans under the Social Security Act. The cumulative loan amount for each state cannot exceed 20 percent of the State family assistance grant for fiscal year 2006. Penalties for non-repayment of loans or interest payments are waived for these states. States affected by Hurricane Katrina can use TANF funds to provide benefits and services without limitations. Temporary TANF benefits received by affected families will not trigger work requirements or time limits. Penalties under TANF are waived for hurricane-damaged states. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will not penalize Louisiana, Mississippi, or Alabama for TANF non-compliance due to Hurricane Katrina until the end of fiscal year 2006. All funds in this Act are designated as emergency requirements.
